posts.name: Donovan White
posts.cooked:
Any teams out there interested in a atmega328p based led controller for 5v addressable LED strips? Iâ€™ve noticed the REV blinkin and CTRE CANdle are good led controllers however they are quite expensive and usually are rather difficult to program or they donâ€™t have a ton of customizability. Iâ€™m just asking here to see if it would be worth developing one and making it for sale.

Iâ€™m aware there are good options for on-robot LEDs, but would having one that can do other things such as robot-cart lighting, pit lighting, etc, be of any use to teams? I appreciate any feedback!

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: You can control the LEDs via connecting to power to a VRM and programming with a roborio, so I donâ€™t know what is the advantage to using something like the blinkin or CANdle

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: If I were you, I might reconsider using the atmega328p as it is becoming phased out and is not recommended for new designs according to Microchip .

posts.name: Donovan White
posts.cooked: Iâ€™m aware of that, just using it as an example for the concept and maybe the initial prototype.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
If you want customizable, the PixelBlaze platform has some ridiculously powerful pattern configuration and installation tools. https://electromage.com/docs/intro-to-mapping . This also has an open source library to tap into this capability on custom boards.

For things on carts and off-robot, the WLED platform is ESP32 based with good configuration apps, which provides open source budget options. Or, for many smaller projects a $5 Pi Pico works.

As for goals, anytime you aim to undercut pricing, youâ€™ll probably run into the same problems that  showcase why itâ€™s expensive, but only after having sunk development costs. The bulk of component cost in Blinkin and CANdle are in power management for high current outputs on ridiculously unclean power in a robot environment. If youâ€™re not operating on a robot, the majority of those costs are unnecessary, and undercutting things is pretty trivial. But, by the same metric, cheaper, standard components already exist. Not trying to discourage product development as a summer project: But just be aware that this particular goal is probably not the right one to chase after.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
Donâ€™t ask me why, but I seem to have a bit of a passion for addressable LEDâ€™s and controllers. Just ask my wife. 328pâ€™s are fine for smaller setups, but they lack memory to do much more than a couple dozen LEDs. They struggle with more than one strand, but can handle it if you are super careful in your code. They have one advantage though, they have +5v logic signal out.

I would suggest looking into some of the simple esp8266, or even better, esp32, boards. For example, we ran an esp8266 D1 Mini board, powered by a Polulu +5v regulator to drive a couple of strip on our bot this year. The 8266 is capable of running your own home brewed code or something as sweet as WLED . It only has +3.3v logic out, so you need to keep the run to the first LED quite short. If that is not possible, simply add a logic level shifter and you are good to go. For example, this one by Adafruit .

If you step to an esp32 you can drive multiple strings quite easily, even under WLED. Again, level shifting might need to take place.

We controlled our LED code via serial packets sent from the Rio to the controller over USB. Simple, sweet, and candy for the eyes.

Aw, @tekdemo beat me to it

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
I am thinking make one that use ESP32 and SPI strips connected via CAN .

However I havenâ€™t figure out best way of implementing control. The most flexible method would be allow pixel level update. However this could create significant amount of CAN traffic which could impact more critical stuff on the robot like motor controllers.

Alternatively I could have several preset pattern on ESP32 and no pixel level control.

Which one do you prefer? Need some suggestions?

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked:
CAN based control and/or support for 12v LED strips.

I think they also have onboard storage for LED patterns, which can reduce cpu load on the Rio, but I donâ€™t know how much of an actual concern that is on your average robot.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: One of the reasons I prefer the esp32/esp8266 controllers is that you can create dozens of animations using the Adafruit Neopixel libraries .

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Welcome! Youâ€™ll get a lot of advice on this topic for sure :). I can speak with a tiny bit of experience in this space.

comandd:

usually are rather difficult to program or they donâ€™t have a ton of customizability

First things first - these are competing goals - as you decrease programming complexity, you also decrease customizability. If nothing else, before outlaying money on hardware, Iâ€™d recommend mocking up your development environment and user interface that hits the â€œsweet spotâ€ between these. Getting that reviewed and â€œrightâ€ will be a pre-step to success.

Some experience I bring to the table: Iâ€™ve done very similar exercises for my own team .

We only made a few prototypes, but I did price out costs for more. At a small (500 units) production run, hereâ€™s a quick rundown of costs:

PCB, components, assembly, shipping from factory->my house - $15/each

Up-front engineering cost: 40 hours, which Iâ€™ll bill myself at $100/hour - $4000 total, or $8 per unit.

Letâ€™s assume another $3 per unit for packaging and shipping.

Case, 3d printed - $1 per unit, plus probably about $2 per unit of labor to maintain the printer and assemble the final units

With no software support, weâ€™re conservatively at $29 already minimum costs, with no profit margin to help you expand the business. Thatâ€™s getting real darn close to Revâ€™s ~$50 blinkin.

But, then again, consider that youâ€™ll have to also pay for:

Logistics - someoneâ€™s gotta put labels on boxes and drop them in the mailbox

Software - I just used the STM32 Cube IDE to program - if youâ€™re inventing a layer on top, that will take more engineering time and effort

Ongoing hardware support - if you ship hardware, you have to account for the fact some hardware will break. Youâ€™ll need to spend time troubleshooting with customers, providing prompt responses, and shipping them new hardware gratis

Ongoing software support - See above, but for whatever software you ship.

Trying to break into an existing already competitive market with a lower-cost solution is impossible unless you have some really innovative cost reduction. IMO, the easier way to break in is to innovate something thatâ€™s better than most of whatâ€™s on the market, and then charge a premium for it. Especially for the LED market (where a team can always fall back on a $5 arduino and a bit of soldering), that would be my ticket to success.

ALL that being saidâ€¦  I still encourage you to start the journey! Thereâ€™s a ton to be learned even in just the initial engineering, and if you do nothing but make a prototype your team can still benefit from using it next season.
